categories.title: Gizmo Tool Development and Community Feedback in Hyperfy

content.text: The Gizmo tool in Hyperfy has undergone significant development, with a focus on improving user experience and technical capabilities. Key enhancements include rotation snapping, grid snapping for translation, and the ability to toggle between world and local axes using the 'T' key. While snap points were considered, they were ultimately rejected due to poor UX. A toggle key for snapping was requested by users.

Community feedback on the Gizmo tool has been largely positive. Users like nightshiffty and devbyte_00 praised its intuitive design and ease of use. cheddarqueso highlighted useful features such as keyboard shortcuts, snap-to-rotate, and drag-and-drop functionality. However, they also requested additional features like object scaling and collider setup for VIPE houses.

Scaling support for the Gizmo is planned but considered a larger project. Users also expressed interest in a first-person build mode or drone camera to enhance solo building UX. Suggestions included toggling between player and camera modes and adding a fixed reticle or free mouse editing.

The Gizmo tool is being developed with a focus on maintaining consistency with existing UX paradigms. ashxn.eth emphasized that the new system builds on the current one without deviating significantly. Community members were encouraged to provide feedback during early testing phases.

Several action items and feature requests emerged from the discussions. These include adding object scaling, implementing a snapping toggle, improving the outliner with a 'zoom to' feature, and supporting invisible walls. Users also requested better control UI, a vault system for avatar switching, and a code editor with tabs for managing multiple apps.

Documentation needs were identified, including guides for Blender optimization, lightmap baking workflows, and Gizmo keyboard shortcuts. These resources aim to support users in adopting new features and improving their development pipelines.

categories.title: Hyperfy Platform Development and UX Enhancements

content.text: The Hyperfy community has been actively developing and refining several core features of the platform, with a strong focus on improving the user experience (UX), building tools, and deployment workflows. A major highlight is the ongoing development of the Gizmo tool, which now includes rotation snapping, grid snapping for translation, and toggling between world and local axes. Users have requested additional features such as object scaling, snapping toggles, and a 'zoom to' function for selected nodes. A first-person drone-based build mode was introduced to enhance solo building UX, allowing users to build while flying and keeping their avatar visible to others.

Skinned mesh support has been added, enabling developers to render animated characters with bone transforms and animation blending. Emotes currently use a fixed fade time, with plans to make this configurable. There are also discussions around supporting pets and mounts using skinned meshes. Optimization guidance was provided for Blender workflows, including UV unwrapping and texture memory management. However, compressed Draco GLBs are not yet supported in version 2.

Deployment issues were addressed, particularly for users hosting on Digital Ocean. The main problem stemmed from incorrect .env configurations using 'localhost' instead of the public IP. HTTPS is required for file hashing and uploads, and users were advised to ensure their .env values match the access method. Documentation updates were suggested to clarify these requirements.

The app architecture was clarified: all nodes remain tied to their originating app, even when moved to world space. Events should only pass JSON data to avoid undefined behavior. Cloning nodes requires clone(true) to include children, and rigidbodies must use setPosition() instead of directly modifying position.

Community feedback has been instrumental in shaping new features. Users praised the Gizmo tool’s intuitive design and requested enhancements like object scaling and collider setup. Lightmap testing was introduced for shooter arenas, and AI texture generation tools like poly.cam were explored. A vault system for avatar switching is planned, and a code editor with tab support for multiple apps was proposed.

Additional feature requests include invisible walls, toggleable control UIs, bounding box-based entity streaming, and mobile-specific controls like a jump button. The team is also considering wallet-based login and .hyp file integration for external games. These suggestions reflect a growing interest in expanding Hyperfy’s capabilities for both creators and players.
